sponsor.partnerMessage: Want to get your product off the shelf and into carts? Soapbox Influence builds brands through authentic conversion with influencer marketing, shopper insights, and social media management. Get started HERE.

posts.title: The Beach Boys Will Surf Through NWA This Fall
posts.content:
The Beach Boys will bring their iconic California sound to Fayetteville this fall, making an appearance at Walton Arts Center for their America's Band Tour on Wednesday, Sep 27.

  • Surf's up: Lead-singer Mike Love wrote the lyrics to the Boys' first hit, Surfin', in 1961, and in the five decades since, the band has sold over 100m records worldwide, been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and received the lifetime achievement award at the Grammy Awards.
  • Wouldn't It Be Nice: Don't miss the opportunity to sing along with the iconic band that captured the spirit of American youth in the 1960s with unforgettable anthems like Surfin' USA, California Girls, Good Vibrations, and Kokomo.

Tickets go on sale this Friday, Jun 16, at 10a. Save the link HERE.

posts.title: Kickstart Your Thursdays With Breathwork & Flow Yoga At Red Barn
posts.content:
Start your Thursday mornings with Breathwork & Flow Yoga at Red Barn Bentonville — Arkansas's first agri-hood, an agricultural-centered community just minutes from Downtown Bentonville.

  • Meditation: Every Thursday at 6a, join yoga instructor Sharlotte Fedewa at the barn for an hour of breathwork and meditation, and begin your day by activating your body's energy.
  • Caffeination: Stop by the Grange after the class and try a cup of Red Barn's farm-roasted coffee, ethically sourced and roasted on-site in a state-of-the-art, zero-emission Bellwether Roaster.

Everyone's first class is free. Find more info HERE.

posts.title: Anthony Timberlands Center Featured By Architectural Record
posts.content:
Architectural Record recently featured a list of projects around the world that demonstrate unique uses of wood, including The Anthony Timberlands Center for Design and Materials Innovation — currently under construction at the University of Arkansas.

  • Ark-Irish: In collaboration with Modus Studio, the project is the first U.S. build and the first timber build for Pritzker Prize–winning firm Grafton Architects of Dublin. Using Arkansas-sourced timber, the $26.5m building will include a high-bay fabrication workshop, studios, conference rooms, faculty offices, and outdoor terraces.
  • Cool school: As part of the Fay Jones School of Architecture and Design, the center will be home to the school’s growing design-build program and fabrication technologies laboratories and will house the school’s emerging graduate program in timber and wood design.

Learn more about the project HERE.

posts.title: AR-112 Construction Project Unearths Ancient Artifacts
posts.content:
The Commonwealth Heritage Group has been called in to excavate a significant archaeological site found during a survey for the upcoming Hwy 112 expansion project near the Blessings Golf Club.

  • Dig this: Estimated to be 6,000-9,000 years old, the site is thought to have been home to a community of 30-50 people living in huts surrounding a 30 ft cookhouse filled with fire hearths. Senior archaeologist Jack Rossen called it the most significant archaeological site he's seen in Arkansas.
  • Ancient artifacts: The site will be excavated and artifacts taken to Memphis to gain insight into the lifestyle of the people who once lived there before the site it cleared to make way for the highway construction.

Read more on the story from 5News HERE.

posts.title: Fayetteville Prepares For Nelson Hackett Celebration
posts.content:
The City of Fayetteville will unveil a new historical marker and street renaming in honor of Nelson Hackett with a ceremony and celebration at the Pryor Center and Downtown Square this Friday, Jun 16, from 4-7:30p.

  • Nelson Hackett's 1841 escape from slavery in Fayetteville and extradition from Canada played a significant role in American abolition and emancipation, even going on to influence international relations and law. His story has been preserved by the U of A's Nelson Hackett Project and the Black Heritage Preservation Commission.
  • Following the ceremony, a reception will be held at the Juke Joint exhibit in the atrium of the Pryor Center from 6:30-7:30p, featuring music from Delta bluesman Keith Johnson and refreshments from local bakery Rollin' in the Dough.

Learn more about Nelson Hackett and the event HERE.

pick.title: NWA Daily Picks
pick.content:
• 🎟 Turn up the music & hit the open road: In Best Musical Violet, a young woman in 1964 travels across Arkansas toward a miracle in Tulsa and begins the journey of a lifetime. On stage at TheatreSquared now-Jul 2.*
  • 🪕 Mountain music: Celebrate 100 years of Mount Sequoyah Center's programming during the 3rd Annual Chamber Music On The Mountian event, this year featuring Arkansas composers, folk traditions, and music from the 1920s.*
  • 🧹 Clean home, happy heart! Reach out to NWA Cleaners to get your home, short-term rental, or Airbnb cleaned. Get a quote HERE.*
  • 💪 Dad strength: Burn Bootcamp Fayetteville is celebrating Father's Day by offering Dudes & Dads free workout classes all week, Jun 12-17. Attend at least two camps to be entered into a drawing for Luke Bryan tickets and a Golf USA gift card!
  • 🥷 Leaps and bounds: Don Tyson School of Innovation student Joseph Rouse took on the world-famous obstacle course of American Ninja Warrior last night on NBC.
  • 🃏 Are you watching closely? Zachary Gibson will bring his comedic magic and hypnosis act to Brick & Mortar this Friday, Jun 16, from 7:15-8:30p.
  • 📅 Local happenings: Explore upcoming events mentioned in the newsletter, or post your own HERE!
